ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Both TA's were excellent. I think they complemented each other very well. I'd say they were the two best TA's I had during my two years at F&ES.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  MD.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  + Kris Covey.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  And Kris Covey. Both were great.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  marlyse duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  great teaching fellow, very knowledgeable, frank and open to questions and comments. great resource and addition to the class
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Both Marlyse and Chris were excellent and essential! They both understand how to work well with Mark, and therefore made the class very enjoyable and smooth!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  (there is no prompt question here... i interacted most closely with Marlyse, whom I have already selected from the dropdown list...)
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is great! In all the interaction I had with her, she was really helpful, and she's extremely knowledgeable.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is a wonderful and knowledgeable person, as is Kristofer Covey.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid was a wonderful TA. She was extremely helpful in answering my questions about class lectures and during class field trips, as well as giving me helpful tips for studying for the exams and how to best manage the reading load. On a personal level, she was extremely considerate of my special circumstances and did her very best to make sure that I was able to participate comfortably on field trips.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  marlyse
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Kristopher Covey
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse and Kris Covey

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: As an MEM, Silviculture was a stretch. I dont know tree ID, i didn't take stands, etc. It's a lot of information. a ton of material- the most. but it is, i think, indeed the quintessential Yale Forestry course. Some say its stand dynamics, but there's no one like Mark Ashton, especially in the woods.its really really an ecology course, so watch out. Those interested in Management plans, or land management more generally, you may be disappointed (as i was) that there isn't more landscape scale stuff.its four credits for a reason get ready to work.the reading blows but it helps.
No matter what you are studying at F&ES, you should take silviculture with Dr. Ashton. He's the man.

the presentation of the course could be more on point. consistent reading assignment load with more applicable reading would be helpful. it would also be helpful if the slides were a better resource. the way the course is presented it is hard to know what is important. we cover broad general strokes in class and minutia in exams.
#2 An occasional written assignment would have been appreciated.#7 If all the field trips are crammed into one month...its too many.
Thanks for an excellent course with a strong community-building component

There are a lot of field trips but all of them were different and provided great information to compliment what we were learning in class! Both the teaching fellows were great and necessary to help the class go smoothly. They provided alternative means of explaining concepts if Mark Ashton could not get the idea across. The reading load was heavy but not essential to understand the material or pass the exams--maybe make them more necessary if so many are going to be assigned. The exams were very fair, and I was glad not to have to write the prescription. I felt the workload adequately reflected the 4 credits earned and the amount of effort I put towards the class!
Dr. Ashton's the best!

One area of improvement could have been to have more assignments along the way. The primary mode of evaluation was through exams and class attendance/participation, but I felt like I would have been able to better integrate the material if there had been a couple of small assignments over the course of the semester--so that we could have seen how well we were putting material together and also to give us an additional opportunity to engage more with the material.
It would have been helpful if the tutorials were more structured and reviewed key themes. The Q&A format was not very helpful.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Mark Ashton is great, he truly cares about students and the subject matter. The field trips were a great learning experience and very practical, refreshing experience!
mark in the woods- field trips. the overnight at myers.
Best aspect were the field trip and the part of the class about silvicultural treatments. Also silviculture charades at YMF.
Dr. Ashton and field trips.
field trips! especially the multi-day one. i loved the prescriptions too - site prep, regeneration strategies, post -establishment.
Field trips! Best learning happens in the field, hands down.
Lectures and field exercises
Field applications

Mark Ashton is incredibly knowledgable!! The concepts taught in Silviculture are not taught in any other course, making this class essential for Masters of Forestry candidates, and anyone interested in the practice of forests.
The field trips were the best opportunity to learn the course material.
Field trips.
Mark Ashton himself. Even for someone who has no particular interest in silviculture, he is so engaging and enthusiastic.
Field trips were very helpful to put the conceptual material in to context.
The field trips were the richest experience of the course, allowing me to apply principles from class in the forest.
The field trips were great. The overall culture created by the professor and TAs--there was a strong sense of community that was unique to this class. Also evident passion by the professor and TAs.
All aspects were interesting to me
The field trips

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: is there any way to decrease the content? i dunno probably not.

the non-prescription parts of the course were not well integrated. the science at the beginning and management applications at the end in particular.it would be really helpful if there were homework assignments - 1 page questionnaires or problem sets so it is not just one exam. applying the material and checking up on understanding periodically would be awesome.
Lectures could be better organized, but I get the sense that they don't change very often...
N/A

Field trips need to be more interactive...most of our field time was spent being "talked at". The lecture took place in the forest but failed to really take advantage of being in the forest. This course requires much more discussion and student engagement.Why is forest policy and administration not touched upon? Should not forest measurements and inventory be more emphasized?
Pare down the reading list and a more detailed roadmap/overview of the concepts. Key concepts and phrases for each day on the syllabus would be great
first month was slow and repetitive
The lectures could be a bit more interactive and engaging.

Start the course on time! The course is scheduled to start at 8:30. It generally started at 8:45. Waiting around for late students just perpetuates the problem and is unfair for those who arrive on time.
Slides from powerpoint presentations should be accompanied with a little more explanation.

I would be helpful to have a "required" and "optional" reading list, in order to help students to prioritize their efforts in reading for the class and preparing for exams. Also, it would be nice to have more time during each lecture for Q&A.

More opportunity to practice and be challenged by the material---the exams were a good start, but more practice along the way.I would also have appreciated being assigned a few more academic papers that are considered seminal in this field...
The tutorials: I wish they were more structured and reviewed key themes of the course so I could better keep up with the lectures.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: there should be more discussion sections, and the TAs shouldn't be so transparent about hating it. maybe be upfront with TAs about the commitment of being available outside of class.
Very effective. It ties together the themes and topics discussed in lecture very well.
N/A
A discussion section should be added!
There was no lab section. But the field trips were really good.
Prepared TA recaps vs. solely Q&A would be great
The TF-lead discussions were very helpful and a great opportunity to get questions answered and concepts clarified!
Lectures and field trips were well integrated.
Yes, very effective
See previous responses.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Kris is a great lecturer. Marlyse is organized and helps manage the logistics of the class. Again, I would have benefitted from more structured tutorials.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Both Kris and Marlyse were available, dedicated, and responsive. Kudos to Marlyse for taking the time to drive students to the field practicum. Kris' lecture about pruning was really, really great. He'll make an awesome teacher. Also, thanks for the coffee, guys :-)
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Both were great.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  the review sessions were good!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Great fellow. We didn't have section, but review sections were fabulous.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse and Chris really know what they are talking about! There were accessible and easy to approach! They gave great advice and were able to answer everyone's questions adequately!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  marlyse was very organized and helpful

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Kris Covey gave a lecture but apart from that, clearly relied on Marlyse to do most of the work and functions of a TF. How TFs split the work should be revisited, if there are to be 2 of them again - I felt Marlyse was doing more than her fair share.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is very responsive to students and a clear and enthusiastic teacher.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was extremely well organized and was instrumental in making the field trips run smoothly and keeping track of time. Also, she was great at answering questions in a way that we could easily understand and remember. She is also very considerate of students' individual needs.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is knowledgable and organized. She is attentive to student's interests and needs.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse demonstrated in-depth knowledge in the subject and was able to explain concepts to the class level

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: More personal edification and to gain perspective on the history of FES, and an appreciation for natural resource management.
it doesnt really fit, im an MEM but i felt like i had to. Im at Yale Forestry for god sakes. Glad to get back up to myers.
Answer further down.
Trees are the answer.

The course fits in my academic overall program as it provides a well understanding of the basic principles of forest management and reforestation program for different social values, including conservation, timber production and watershed management. I would recommend a chapter where students can lear about managing different forest types around the world-- this may be through topic discussions.
This course is the backbone of the MF program! No one should consider working in forested locations without taking this course!

this is a foundation for forestry and might be better if in the first semester. the forestry curriculum needs more of this type of specific forest management field work, a la forest crew but during the academic year
Essential
FES needs more classes like this.
As an MF, this course is the crucial to my overall program.
It really doesn't at all, but I'm still glad I took it!
Required, and appropriately so.

I'm interested in sustainable forestry in Latin America. Even though this course was more focused on temperate forests, it gave me an important foundation of forestry concepts that will help me with further coursework and my career.
It was a great introduction to forestry concepts---it is a central component to my academic interests

As a wood scientist, silviculture has enabled me appreciate the relevance of tending to forest to achieve certain desirable products in a sustained way. This was never of concern to me until now and yet as the most important.
It does not fit very well. I am interested in environmental advocacy. I suppose my understanding of silviculture gives me more perspective but I'm not confident that it applies.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: to feel like a 1900 era forester.
Because it is the silviculture class, and I'm an MF.
Because I was interested in trees and plants. It's a great course.
required! also interested!
Interest in urban forestry issues.
Important for my academic goals.
To take a course at the core of the Yale School of Forestry's identity
I took this course to gain the knowledge that Mark Ashton provides! He is a great professor and this course was wonderful!
Content fits very well with my academic goalsWell-reputed instructor and course format (field trips)
As an MF this is an incredibly important course to take.
Because it's the "classic" FES course, and I'm glad that this alone made me take the course.
Interest.
To give me a foundational understanding of forestry concepts.
The subject matter was my primary motivator as well as hearing strong praise for the professor.
To have knowledge how forests exist and what silviculture was all about having interest in forest science. This turned out to be extremely useful.
I heard it was a great class.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes! i learned a lot.

I'm going to answer all the other questions here.No, the skills gained from the course did not meet my expectations, as much as I love Dr. Ashton and his immense dedication to his students.I felt that this class was watered down in terms of content to fit a generalist background. Which makes it good for MEM students, and I'm really glad that we have them because it gives the class a critical mass. I'm aware that this class is the "flagship" class for MEMs interested in forestry.But I came to the school to get a Master of Forestry. And here I am, taking Silviculture because this is our only silviculture class, and learning, over the course of ONE SINGLE CLASS, about the whole discipline once called Silvics, about principles of Forest Ecology, Silviculture, site treatments and planting, wildlife habitat, forest operations, landscape architecture, urban forestry.Don't get me wrong: this diversity of issues make the class interesting, and the way Mark Ashton works to integrate all of them is nice. We get a holistic view.But I took Forest Operations with Mike Ferrucci, and the session about forest operations was redundant to me. And I took Stand Dynamics, and the session about stand dynamics was redundant to me. And I took Forest Health, and the class about wildlife habitat was redundant to me.On the other hand, I never had to opportunity to take a class about forest ecology, and it will never be offered to me during my curriculum.More importantly, I will never have the opportunity to learn more about silvicultural treatments. And this to me is such a huge disappointment. To spend one class one selection systems, one class on shelterwood systems. While all over the world foresters are tearing each other apart debating about single cohort versus multi-age, about "close-to-nature" versus traditional forestry, and so on.I would have loved to learn more about the birth of each of these doctrines and the rationale behind them. Loved to learn about instances where they worked, instances when they failed and why they did. Growth& Yield models. Numbers, quantitative facts about the yield of different approaches. How they can or cannot be implemented depending on your climate, species, yield constraints, and manpower.I would have loved to take an entire class on Forest Ecology/Silvics. An entire class on Silviculture. An entire class about Forest Policy. To cut down on the redundant, superficial content. I guess this is not how the program is built as of today. I suppose we just don't have people to teach these classes.So in short - the instructor is great. But he's trying to teach us both too much in terms of scope, and too little in terms of depth. Should be renamed Introduction to Silviculture.(Yes, I know there's the Southern Fieldtrip and the Germany Fieldtrip and Forest Crew and the opportunity to work at the School Forests Office. Still, the core of what we learn should not depend entirely on extras. We're in Forestry School: the core of what we learn should be what is taught.)
Yes.
yes
Yes.
Yes
No, I found the course somewhat lacking wit regards to the skills taught and the material presented.
Yes!
The knowledge I gained exceeded my expectations! I was completely unfamiliar with any silvicultural concept so I really learned a lot during this semester!
for forestry students, it would be good to be able to focus in more depth on management techniques, logging operations, tree growth, etc.
More on silvicultural prescriptions would be nice. More of the nuance of silvics needed
Yes

The course suffered from having students (mainly MFs) with lots of previous knowledge and students (mainly MEMs) with little background in the material. This made it difficult for both groups to gain the maximum amount from the course.
Yes.

Yes, this course definitely gave me a solid foundation in understanding forestry concepts and applications. It was also really interesting to learn more about the ecology of the forests in which I've lived all my life.
I loved this class. I learned a lot, it absolutely met my expectations.
Yes and actually beyond my expectation
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: You get to meet a bunch of people you might not otherwise have met.
We all worked together so will say there was no disadvantage. I also got clarifications via group members.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: think about it, ask people who have took it- especially if you're an MEM. if youre willing to work, go for it. if you loved mods, go for it.but make no mistake, its an applied ecology course, so be ready.
Take it and go to field trips.
Take it. Go to as many of the field trips as you can.
take notes on your computer during class - find a way not to zone out during presentations.my notes from class - even when i took lots of notes, were often nonsensical
Take good notes, study a lot.
This is the foundation course if you are interested in forest management and restoration. The class is not helpful if you are expecting to stay in the office and not doing field work.
Take Stand Dynamics first, then consider carefully whether you would benefit from Silviculture.
If you have interest in forest ecology. Take it you will learn a lot even without much pressure

I would recommend deciding early whether or not you are going to read for the class. The two main texts helped me, but I didn't bother with the others and I don't feel I suffered for it. Understand that this course demands a lot of time in terms of reading, field trips, and studying for exams.

Requires organization and thoughtful note-taking from the beginning. Regular review of concepts is helpful, as there aren't problem sets to force students to do so, and it's a lot of material for the midterm and final.
I would recommend this course to anyone, including MEMs wanting an overview of forest ecology.
Take it.
Definitely take it, even if you are just auditing, which is what I did. It had no real "relevance" to my course of study, but is such a great class, and Ashton if really a wonderful lecturer.
Pay attention!

If you feel that the lectures are a little too fast, that you're not understanding everything, or that you don't have the forestry background that many other students seem to have, I would read Dr. Ashton's "Applied Silviculture" textbook. It really helped me understand the concepts on a much deeper level.

It depends what you want to get out of it...but, I would highly recommend the course to anyone considering it. It feels like a core class for students at the Forestry school...we spent significant time outdoors, which helped to make concepts more real. The class allowed for different styles of learning--experiential and book.
Every ardent and aspiring environmentalist must take this course. It goes beyond just forests
If you feel you have to take a forestry course, this is the one for you. If you don't need to take a forestry course, I wouldn't bother.
